results.title: Controlled heat
results.creator_credit: Douglas Clarke, Jack Chambers and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: By means of diagrams and photography tells the story of thermostatic control. Shows, in fact, how the expansion of metals when heated can be used to regulate temperatures. The story is treated historically, beginning in the 18th century with the problem of accurate time-keeping, especially for navigation, and leading up to such complicated modern examples as open-hearth steel processing.

results.title: Control your emotions
results.brief_description: A preemptive strike against a generation of uncontrolled, emotional teenagers. “Control your emotions” is hosted by an unnamed expert wearing a white lab coat. He sits behind a desk while moving around blocks labeled RAGE, FEAR and LOVE and a big cardboard disk titled PERSONALITY. He also repeatedly interrupts the story of Jeff Moore, the film’s protagonist, with psychobabble such as, “Your emotions can be your own greatest enemy,” and “Severe emotional stress often decreases efficiency.” Jeff, who has dark circles under his eyes, supposedly has a hard time controlling his emotions. But the only examples shown are of him losing his temper. But by the end of the film Jeff has learned that he’s happiest when reason triumphs over feeling, and he joins the gang at a marshmallow roast.

results.title: The Control of worms in sheep
results.creator_credit: Australian Wool Corporation and Ritter-Jepperson Studios
results.brief_description: Two neighbours, who own adjoining properties, both attempt to combat this disease in their sheep. The sheep in the first property are suffering from the combined effects of overstocking and worm parasites. On the second property, after a period of trial and error, what is termed correct stocking is achieved, and as a result, the worm problem solves itself. The film emphasises that sheep must be drenched at the right time and properly fed all the time.

results.title: The Control of working capital (NP)
results.brief_description: Designed to explain the essentials of business finance to people without any financial background. Uses a dramatic format to explain how a cash crisis can be avoided by reducing working capital in four key areas: purchasing, manufacturing, sales, and credit control. Starring John Cleese and Ronnie Corbett and written by Antony Jay (of “Yes Prime Minister” fame). Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Control of foot rot
results.brief_description: Detailed explanation of causes, symptoms and effective treatment of foot rot in sheep. Isolated cases must be penned separately and the flock checked to ensure that the disease has not spread. In flocks where foot rot is widespread, the only solution is the thorough inspection of all sheep, paring and cutting away all unhealthy tissue and painting with an antibiotic solution, or administering a formalin foot bath.

results.title: Control of body temperature
results.brief_description: By means of laboratory demonstrations, animated drawings, and microphotography, the phenomena associated with variations in body temperature in animals and in human beings are shown. The blood stream is shown to be the distributor of heat energy; foods eaten are, therefore, important to body temperature. The function of the hypothalamus is compared with that of a thermostat.

results.title: Control of bacteria in food
results.creator_credit: J Lyons and Gate Film Production
results.brief_description: A study of bacteria and how they can be controlled in food. Special photographic techniques are used to show the shape of bacteria and their method of multiplying. An experiment demonstrates that bacteria flourish in dirt; thus cleanliness is essential when handling food. Experiments with milk prove that heating destroys bacteria and cooling retards their growth.

results.title: Control by budgeting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Shows how budgets can be prepared to avoid running a business at a loss.

group_siblings.title: Investment planning
group_siblings.creator_credit: David Hargreaves, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV

results.title: Contracting out
results.creator_credit: Bill Davies and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: What can a truck driver do if his company decides to rent trucking services and to let him go? More and more companies find it practical to “contract out” subsidiary operations such as the trucking of their goods, with consequent layoff of some men. A common cause of industrial disputes, this problem is dramatized to provide ground for discussion.

results.title: Contraception
results.creator_credit: Ben Norman, FilmFair Communications and John Wiley
results.brief_description: Points out the needs for contraceptives during intercourse. Shows the various kinds of contraceptives used today, covering the history of its development, physical properties, the contraceptive principle behind it, and using live photography to show how it works. Discusses the advantages, disadvantages and comparative effectiveness of each method.
